head.title: Who Keeps Track Of the Tree-Cutters?

hedline.hl1: Who Keeps Track Of the Tree-Cutters?

block.p: I read with dismay the destruction of Ellen Halloran's beloved tree (''Mourning a Humble Ailanthus,'' Soapbox, Oct. 8). I too lived in the Village with a similar green canopy of trees that have mercifully survived in an odd little green lot on Downing Street, thanks to a trust, rumor has it.
I can attest to the immeasurable serenity and immense pleasures that living in the arms of such a tree can provide a city dweller.

I read with dismay the destruction of Ellen Halloran's beloved tree (''Mourning a Humble Ailanthus,'' Soapbox, Oct. 8). I too lived in the Village with a similar green canopy of trees that have mercifully survived in an odd little green lot on Downing Street, thanks to a trust, rumor has it.
I can attest to the immeasurable serenity and immense pleasures that living in the arms of such a tree can provide a city dweller.

But the point is, who makes the decisions that the trees have to go, and are these decisions monitored? Are considerations given to the plus side of ''watchful waiting'' for a tree that has been pronounced terminal? We need a tree brigade to police the (I suspect) hasty choppers who have experienced that sweet sense of urban tree bliss that comes from having your own personal city tree: winter, spring, summer and fall.
